Award.AwardTitle: Advanced Composites Manufacturing and Repair Using Integrated Distributed Actuation and Dynamic Network Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Because of their high stiffness and light weight, composites such as carbon-fiber reinforced polymers are finding increased use in the automotive, aerospace, and marine transportation sectors and in renewable energy systems such as large wind turbines. An important step in the manufacture of many composites is high-temperature curing, which involves cycling the part through a precise temperature sequence in a sealed pressure vessel called an autoclave. This project focuses on the joining of these finished individual parts to form a complete product. While mechanical fasteners or low-temperature adhesives have inferior performance to high-temperature composite bonds, the assembled system is far too large to place in an autoclave as a unit. This project considers the use of embedded heaters distributed throughout the joint to execute the necessary thermal cycle. So as not to compromise the integrity of the structure, these heaters are made using the same carbon-fiber material as the rest of the composite structure. In preliminary tests this approach has produced joints that equal autoclaved parts in quality; the challenge addressed by this project is achieving such a result over a large, complex structure, such as an airplane wing. This will be done by repurposing advanced control techniques originally developed for networks of dynamic systems, such as mobile robots. The same approach may be used to repair damaged or fatigued composite systems, economically and sustainably extending the useful life of expensive infrastructure. The most advanced technology is useless without a trained workforce capable of employing it. This project will provide training and education to undergraduate and graduate students in advanced manufacturing and controls, and the results will be used in outreach and recruitment to high-school students.

A network of multiple distributed heaters that can account for variations in heat loss, e.g., due to uneven sub-structures, and enable uniform temperatures at the bondline for consistent curing of the adhesive are planned. The control challenge arises from differences in the thermal dynamics of each of the distributed heater system (input voltage to local temperature) in the network due to differences in material properties (e.g., thickness of composites) and boundary conditions (e.g., due to the presence of substructures). Current iterative approaches for networked multi-agent systems are mostly applicable to homogenous agent dynamics. It is challenging to prove convergence of iterative learning for heterogeneous, networked multi-agent systems when the dynamics of the different agents are general linear systems. A novel inversion-based iterative control is planned that can correct for the dynamics of each agent and, thereby, can achieve the desired output specified through the network. The intellectual merit of the research is to develop conditions that quantify the acceptable modeling uncertainty for ensuring convergence of iterative approaches in the presence of heterogeneity. Thus, the research will advance the state-of-the-art in iterative-learning theory for networked multi-agent systems and its applicability to important technological problems such as manufacturing.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to understand iterative approaches for co-operative tracking in networked heterogeneous multi-agent systems (MAS) to enable a novel, adhesive-bonding approach for joining high-strength (carbon-fiber) composite components.  Rather than heat the entire system (which is not energy-efficient) to cure the adhesive at the bondline, the research will investigate an out-of-autoclave, controlled heating targeted at the bondline with an embedded heater. To enable uniform temperatures for consistent curing of the adhesive, a network of multiple distributed heaters was proposed that can account for variations in heat loss, e.g., due to uneven sub-structures.  Iterative consensus and co-operative tracking (that account for modeling uncertainties in networked MAS) are well suited to achieve temperature uniformity (consensus) and co-operative tracking of the desired temperature (time) profile during adhesive curing.

A novel model-inversion-based, iterative approach was proposed for heterogeneous networked MAS in the presence of modeling uncertainties. The challenge in temperature control arises from differences in the thermal dynamics (input voltage to local temperature) of each of the distributed heater system in the network due to differences in material properties (e.g., thickness of composites) and boundary conditions (e.g., due to the presence of substructures).  Current iterative approaches for networked MAS are mostly applicable to homogenous agent dynamics --- it is challenging to prove convergence of iterative learning for heterogeneous networked multi-agent systems when the dynamics of the different agents are general linear systems. This challenge was addressed in the proposed work.

Impact: The research enables societally important applications by reducing manufacturing cost. Carbon fiber reinforced polymer (CFRP) composites with a thermoset resin such as epoxy can lead to some of the highest strength-to-weight ratio and rigidity. Therefore, CFRPs have been used in aerospace, sailing boats, and top-end bicycles, cars and motorcycles. However, the need to use autoclaves to cure the thermoset resin implies that these composites can be expensive to manufacture. In particular, the cost of manufacturing with autoclaves tends to be prohibitive as the size of the part increases, e.g., in wind-turbines since the renewable-energy industry is very sensitive to the cost of energy. Hence, reducing the manufacturing cost of high strength composites can directly impact their wider use in societally important applications.

Impact on training and professional Development: The research of PhD students (Nathan Banka, Brandon Smith, and Mahdi Ashrafi) and MS student Case Carte was supported by the grant. Four undergraduate students (Jesse A. Hernandez, Nini T. Hong, Lexi L. Rohrer and Karli Justine Berger) participated through a research experience for undergraduates (REU) supplement.

Publications

Journal

  • S. Devasia, Iterative Learning Control with Time-Partitioned Update for Collaborative Output Tracking, Automatica, Vol. 69C, pp. 258-264, July 2016.
  • S. Devasia, Inversion-based Iterative Learning for Networked Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems, IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control, IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control, Vol. 62 (1), pp. 431-437, Jan. 2017.
  • M. Ashrafi, B. P. Smith, S. Devasia, and M. E. Tuttle, Embedded Resistive Heating in Composite Scarf Repairs, Journal of Composite Materials, Vol. 51 (18), pp. 2575-2583, Aug. 2017
  • B. P. Smith, M. Ashrafi, M. E. Tuttle, and S. Devasia, Boundary Control of Embedded Heaters for Uniform Bondline Temperature during Composite Joining, ASME Journal of Manufacturing Science and Engineering, Vol. 140, Article number 091013, pp. 1-9, Sept. 2018.
  • S. Devasia, Iterative Machine Learning for Output Tracking, IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology, Vol. 27 (2), pp. 516-526, March 2019, https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8167302.
  • N. Banka and S. Devasia, Application of Iterative Machine Learning for Output Tracking with Soft Magnetic Actuators,, ASME/IEEE Transactions on Mechatronics, Vol. 23(5), pp. 2186-2195, October 2018, https://doi.org/10.1109/TMECH.2018.2855217.

 

Conference

  • B. Smith, M. Ashrafi, M. Tuttle and S. Devasia, Boundary Control on Embedded Heaters for Composites Joining, Accepted, to be presented at the ASME Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC), USC, Los Angeles, CA, June 4-8, 2017.
  • S. Devasia, Rapid Information Transfer in Swarms under Update-Rate-Bounds using Delayed Self Reinforcement, Proceedings of the ASME 2018 Dynamic Systems and Control Conference (DSCC), Sep. 30-Oct. 3, Atlanta, GA, USA
  • Anuj Tiwari and Santosh Devasia, Cohesive Velocity Transitions in Platoons without Centralized Communication using Delayed Self Reinforcement, Accepted to poster session in the 2019 ASME Dynamic Systems and Control Conference (DSCC), Park City, Utah

Undergraduate Publications

  • J. A. Hernandez and N. T. Hong, Swarm Robotics, 20th Annual University of Washington Undergraduate Research Symposium, May 19th 2017, U. of Washington, Seattle
  • ] Lexi L. Rohrer, Principles for applying augmented reality to manufacturing, 21th Annual University of Washington Undergraduate Research Symposium, May 18th 2018, U. of Washington, Seattle
  • Alexandra (Lexi) Rohrer and Rose Hendrix, Principles for applying augmented reality in manufacturing, MIT IEEE Undergraduate Research Technology Conference (URTC), October 5-7, 2018, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA
  • Karli Berger, Human-Swarm Interface Design, 22nd Annual University of Washington Undergraduate Research Symposium, May 17th 2019, U. of Washington, Seattle

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of the project was to understand iterative approaches for co-operative tracking in networked heterogeneous multi-agent systems (MAS) to enable a novel, adhesive-bonding approach for joining high-strength (carbon-fiber) composite components. Rather than heat the entire system (which is not energy-efficient) to cure the adhesive at the bondline, the research will investigate an out-of-autoclave, controlled heating targeted at the bondline with an embedded heater. To enable uniform temperatures for consistent curing of the adhesive, a network of multiple distributed heaters was proposed that can account for variations in heat loss, e.g., due to uneven sub-structures. Iterative consensus and co-operative tracking (that account for modeling uncertainties in networked MAS) are well suited to achieve temperature uniformity (consensus) and co-operative tracking of the desired temperature (time) profile during adhesive curing. A novel model-inversion-based, iterative approach was proposed for heterogeneous networked MAS in the presence of modeling uncertainties. The challenge in temperature control arises from differences in the thermal dynamics (input voltage to local temperature) of each of the distributed heater system in the network due to differences in material properties (e.g., thickness of composites) and boundary conditions (e.g., due to the presence of substructures). Current iterative approaches for networked MAS are mostly applicable to homogenous agent dynamics --- it is challenging to prove convergence of iterative learning for heterogeneous networked multi-agent systems when the dynamics of the different agents are general linear systems. This challenge was addressed in the proposed work. Impact: The research enables societally important applications by reducing manufacturing cost. Carbon fiber reinforced polymer (CFRP) composites with a thermoset resin such as epoxy can lead to some of the highest strength-to-weight ratio and rigidity. Therefore, CFRPs have been used in aerospace, sailing boats, and top-end bicycles, cars and motorcycles. However, the need to use autoclaves to cure the thermoset resin implies that these composites can be expensive to manufacture. In particular, the cost of manufacturing with autoclaves tends to be prohibitive as the size of the part increases, e.g., in wind-turbines since the renewable-energy industry is very sensitive to the cost of energy. Hence, reducing the manufacturing cost of high strength composites can directly impact their wider use in societally important applications.
